Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Confocal Microscope

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This proposal is directed at purchasing a confocal microscope to be used by several teams of interdisciplinary scientists for research and education at Western University of Health Sciences (WesternU), and to be shared with various neighboring Institutions (Cal State Fullerton University, Cal Poly Pomona, and the Claremont Colleges). Specifically, this project will not only gradually replace the current and outdated confocal microscope but will add the following research capabilities: live imaging with less phototoxicity, spectral imaging, faster imaging, allowing for accurate FRET analysis, and high-resolution 3D imaging. The requested equipment will be located in a Core Facility dedicated to imaging technologies, and will be accessible to qualified researchers and students. This instrument will also be used to train postdoctoral fellows, graduate students and undergraduate students from the neighboring Institutions in imaging techniques. Finally, it will also be used in a partnering program with a neighboring High School, Garey High School, directed at enhancing their STEM programs. Overall, the project is significant in that it will provide state-of-the-art research capability to both WesternU and to the region. It will also provide valuable research training and experience for student users as well, and facilitate collaborative research between WesternU and neighboring institutions.

The microscope will be used by at least 10 primary research teams of WesternU, and will be used for several research projects: Analysis of protein-protein interactions by several investigators investigating signaling pathways involved in regulation of protein synthesis, receptor trafficking, and synaptic function and plasticity; Analysis of calcium imaging in various neuronal populations in response to a variety of extracellular signals; 3D reconstruction of neuronal dendrites under different physiological or pathological conditions; Analysis of neurogenesis and synaptogenesis.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Award No. (FAIN): 1625304   

Title: MRI: Acquisition of a Confocal Microscope

Period: Sept 1st, 2016 to August 31st, 2019

 

 

Progress Outcomes Report

 

This NSF MRI grant allowed Western University of Health Sciences to purchase a Zeiss confocal microscope LSM880 with Airyscan. It was delivered at the end of January 2017 and was setup early February. Training for lab personnel took place throughout February. An official inauguration took place on April 29th 2017 in the presence of many faculty members of WesternU, Antonio Gamboa, our collaborator from Garey High School and Dr. Gary Gugelchuk, WesternU Provost.

 

Since 2017, numerous lab members from the groups of users listed in the application have used the confocal and obtained very interesting data, which have been incorporated either in publications (see list of publications) or in grant applications. Due to the quality of the images obtained with the instrument, we were able to publish manuscripts in high impact journals, and to obtain funding, which would not have been possible without this instrument.

 

Since 2017, many undergraduate and graduate students (including those from surrounding universities), as well as DO students have been trained to use the instrument and to get a better appreciation of what can be seen with such an instrument. In addition, many postdoctoral scholars were also trained and have become experts in the use of this instrument.

 

Below is a list of the most significant findings, which were obtained with the use of this instrument.

 

  1. 1.   Baudry lab: One of our projects is directed at testing the effects of selective calpain-2 inhibitors on neuronal injury after TBI or repeated concussions. We have made extensive use of immunohistochemistry to analyze changes in neuronal and glial markers in various brain structures and at various times after TBI or repeated concussions.

 

  1. 2.   Bi lab: One of the projects in the Bi lab is to understand the mechanisms underlying the impairment in synaptic plasticity in Angelman syndrome (AS). A major recent finding has been the identification of the protein p18, a component of the Ragulator complex, which regulated the activity of mTOR, as a target of Ube3a, the ubiquitin ligase, which is deleted in AS. Use of the microscope, which allows not only high resolution imaging of lysosomes but also observing the dynamic movement of lysosomes, was essential to show that p18 was regulated by the proteasome pathway.

 

  1. 3.   Yiling Hong Lab: The lab has developed techniques to use patient-specific induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) derived from healthy and patients to study the pathology underlying various diseases. The patient-specific iPSCs were successfully differentiated into neural progenitor cells (NPCs) and cortical organoids, which are comprised of neurons and astrocytes. Again, the use of the confocal microscope has been critical to analyze the structure and composition of these organoids.

 

  1. 4.    Darmani Lab: One of the projects consists in understanding the function of various brainstem nuclei in the control of vomiting, and the roles of various signaling pathways in the regulation of this function. The confocal microscope allowed to better understand the role of serotonin and the GSK signaling pathway in this regulation.
